questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following antimalarial drugs is a slow acting schizonticide?
questions.explanation:
424 
Sold by @itachibot Pyrimethamine is a slow-acting schizonticide. Female Anopheles mosquito inoculates Plasmodium species in the form of sporozoites into the 
human host during blood meal. Sporozoites migrate to the liver and mature into hepatic 
schizonts. Hepatic schizonts are released into the blood in the form of merozoites. Merozoites in 
the erythrocyte transform into ring form and erythrocytic schizonts. Some merozoites in the blood 
transform into gametocytes. Antimalarial drugs are classified based on their onset of action of schizonticidal function as below: • Fast onset of action • Artemisinin derivatives like artemether , arteether and artesunate are fastest acting • Chloroquine • Intermediate onset of action • Mefloquine • Quinine • Proguanil • Lumefantrine • Slow onset of action • Pyrimethamine • Sulfonamides • Tetracyclines • Clindamycin

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is gametocidal to all the species causing malaria?
questions.explanation:
Primaquine is gametocidal to all species causing malaria. It inhibits transmission of malaria. 425 
Sold by @itachibot The drugs with clinically important gametocidal activity (against all species) are: • High activity: • Artemisinins • Primaquine • Low to moderate activity: • Chloroquine • Quinine • Atovaquone/proguanil • No activity: • Mefloquine • Pyrimethamine • Sulfadoxine • Tetracycline

questions.question:
Question 3: A researcher who was studying plasmodium species decided to visit a malaria-endemic place 
in Odisha to do his clinical study for 5 weeks. He is planning to leave after 2 days. Which of 
the following drugs can be taken as prophylaxis before visiting the malaria-endemic place?
questions.explanation:
Doxycycline can be taken as prophylaxis by the researcher before going to malaria-endemic 
places. Chemoprophylaxis against malaria for travelers: • If the duration of travel is less than 6 weeks then doxycycline 100mg once a day is to be started 2 
days before travel and continued atleast 4 weeks after travel. • If the duration of travel is more than 6 weeks then mefloquine 250mg once a week is to be 
started 2 weeks before travel and continued atleast 4 weeks after travel. 426 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: A 35-year-old woman presented with fever and chills. Peripheral blood smear revealed 
findings suggestive of P. vivax malaria. Which among the following is the most appropriate 
drug for this patient? 419 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Most approproate drug for the treatment of malaria due to P. vivax is chloroquine. P. vivax treatment recommendations are: • Chloroquine-susceptible infections: Chloroquine or artemisinin-based combination therapy 
(ACT). • Chloroquine-resistant infections: ACT is the drug of choice but quinine is used during 1st 
trimester of pregnancy. In the absence of resistance data in the question, chloroquine appears to be the most appropriate 
answer.

questions.question: Question 5: Radical cure is required for malaria caused by which of the following species?
questions.explanation:
Radical cure is required for malaria caused by P. vivax and P. ovale. In case of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale, malarial parasites have an exoerythrocytic 
stage (hypnozoites). In the exoerythrocytic phase malarial parasites are found in the liver that can 
cause relapse of malaria after clinical cure. Therefore, they require radical cure by drugs acting on the exoerythrocytic stage. Primaquine is 
effective against the exoerythrocytic stages of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale in the 
liver. Primaquine is administered for 14 days for radical cure.

questions.question: Question 6: Tafenoquine is used in which of the following conditions?

options.d: Treatment of malaria in children <2 years

questions.explanation:
Tafenoquine is used in the radical cure of Plasmodium vivax. Total eradication of plasmodium 
species which includes clinical curative and hypnozoites phase are called radical cure. Primaquine and tafenoquine (derivative of primaquine) have very high activity against the latent 
tissue forms (hypnozoites) of the species. It is primarily used for the chemoprophylaxis and 
radical cure of P. vivax and P. ovale infections.

questions.question: Question 7: Chloroquine is not useful in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Chloroquine is used in the treatment of systemic lupus erythematosus, porphyria cutanea tarda 
and giardiasis, due to its anti-inflammatory effect; but it is not used in the treatment of Sjogren's 
Syndrome. Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine concentrate in lysosomes and have an anti-inflammatory 
effect. It also has antihistaminic and antiarrhythmic properties. Non-antimalarial uses of choloroquine are: 427 
Sold by @itachibot • Hepatic amoebiasis • Giardiasis • Rheumatoid arthritis • Systemic lupus erythematosus • Discoid lupus erythematosus • Porphyria cutanea tarda • Severe polymorphous light eruption

questions.question:
Question 8: A 26-year-old woman who is 10 weeks pregnant, comes with history of fever and chills. She is 
diagnosed with falciparum malaria. Which of the following drugs will you choose for her 
treatment? 420 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The woman is in the 1st trimester of pregnancy and falciparum malaria during 1st trimester of 
pregnancy is treated with quinine plus clindamycin. Worldwide, most species of Falciparum malaria are resistant to chloroquine. In all trimesters, 
pregnant women diagnosed with uncomplicated malaria caused by chloroquine-resistant P. 
falciparum infection can be treated with a combination of quinine and clindamycin. Quinine is considered the drug of choice in the first trimester. In the second and third trimesters 
artemether-lumefantrine can be used, but not in the first trimester. Vivax malaria during pregnancy is treated with chloroquine as chloroquine is safe in pregnancy 
and children. Clindamycin can be used in children for chloroquine-resistant cases. It is safe to use in children 
and pregnant women. Option B: Doxycycline is useful in the treatment of malaria but not used in pregnancy. Options C and D: Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) is not recommended during the 
1st trimester of pregnancy because of a lack of safety data.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 32-year-old man presents with fever with chills and seizures. On examination, his blood 
pressure was 70/50 mm of Hg and labored breathing was present. Routine blood 
investigations revealed Hb of 4.8 g/dl. ABG was done and the pH was 7.21. Findings in 
peripheral blood smear are shown below. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
This scenario depicts a case of severe complicated falciparum malaria, and the drug of choice in 
this condition is artesunate. The image shows ring forms/early trophozoites in erythrocyte, which 
are binucleate (double chromatin) and this is characteristic of P. falciparum malaria. Severe complicated malaria is caused by P. falciparum and is characterized by hyperparasitemia, 
hyperpyrexia, acidosis, respiratory distress, bleeding manifestation, cardiovascular collapse, renal 
failure and cerebral malaria. As per WHO guidelines, all patients with severe malaria should be treated with intravenous or 
intramuscular artesunate for at least 24 hours. Once the patient recovers and can tolerate oral 
medications, oral ACT for 3 days is recommended. Artemether is used only if parenteral artesunate is not available. 428 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is not a WHO recommended artemisinin-based combination therapy?
questions.explanation: WHO recommended artemisinin-based combination therapies are: • Artemether plus lumefantrine • Artesunate plus pyrimethamine-sulfadoxine • Artesunate plus mefloquine • Artesunate plus amodiaquine • Dihydroartemisinin plus piperaquine

questions.question:
Question 11: You are posted in a health centre in Nagaland as part of your rural service and a patient is 
diagnosed with uncomplicated falciparum malaria. Which of the following artemisinin-based 
combination therapy is recommended by NVBDCP for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) recommended by NVBDCP in the 
north-eastern states is a combination of artemether and lumefantrine. NVBDCP guidelines for the treatment of uncomplicated falciparum cases: • North-eastern states: Artemether-lumefantrine based ACT • Rest of the country: Artesunate-sulfadoxine+pyrimethamine In the north-eastern states (Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Manipur, Meghalaya, Mizoram, Nagaland, 
and Tripura), the presently recommended ACT for P. falciparum malaria is a fixed-dose 
combination of artemether-lumefantrine due to the recent reports of late treatment failures with 
the current combination of AS+SP.

questions.question: Question 12: Loading dose is essential for chloroquine because of which of the following properties?
questions.explanation:
Loading dose is essential for chloroquine because of its property of high volume of distribution. Chloroquine is distributed extensively in the liver, spleen, kidney, lungs, skin and, to a lesser 
extent, brain and spinal cord. Because of extensive tissue binding, a loading dose is required for 
achieving effective plasma concentrations earlier in the therapy.

questions.question:
Question 13: While writing a prescription for a patient diagnosed with malaria, the medical officer 
instructed the patient to take a particular drug along with a high fatty meal. Identify the drug.
questions.explanation:
The drug described here is lumefantrine and its absorption increases when it is administered 
along with fatty food or milk because it is highly lipophilic.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient who was diagnosed with malaria was initiated on treatment about 3 days ago. Now 
she presents with seizures and confusion. Which of the following drugs is most likely to have 
caused this condition? 422 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
429 
Sold by @itachibot The case depicts neuropsychiatric adverse effects which are commonly associated with the use of 
mefloquine. The US FDA has put a "black box warning" for this drug due to permanent and 
serious neuropsychiatric side effects. The CNS toxicity caused by mefloquine includes: • Seizures • Acute psychosis • Severe vertigo • Confusion or decreased sensorium

questions.question: Question 15: The finding shown in the image below is seen as a side effect of which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation:
The finding shown in the image is bulls-eye maculopathy, and chloroquine and 
hydroxychloroquine use are associated with this side effect. Bull's-eye maculopathy refers to the ophthalmoscopic appearance of a central area of retinal 
pigment epithelial depigmentation surrounded by relatively normal retinal pigment epithelium, 
giving a bull's-eye appearance to the macula.

questions.question:
Question 16: A pregnant patient with severe malaria is undergoing treatment with quinine. Which of the 
following adverse effects is not associated with this drug?
questions.explanation:
Quinine is not associated with hypertension. It is associated with hypotension. Quinine is used in the treatment of drug-resistant and severe P. falciparum malaria. It acts against 
asexual erythrocytic forms but has no significant effect on hepatic forms of malarial parasites. Option A: Quinine use is associated with cinchonism which manifests as tinnitus, visual and 
auditory disturbances, headache, nausea, and vomiting. Option B: Quinine has a stimulatory effect on pancreatic beta cells and can cause hypoglycemia. Option D: Blackwater fever is a rare type of hypersensitivity reaction to quinine. It presents 
with massive hemolysis, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria that may lead to anuria, renal 
failure, and death.

questions.question:
Question 17: A patient who was initiated on treatment for malaria two days ago, now presents with 
complaints of passage of dark-colored urine. Hemolysis due to G6PD deficiency is suspected. 
With which of the following drugs is this condition more common?
questions.explanation:
Hemolysis in a G6PD deficient patient is more common with primaquine. G6PD deficient patients are highly sensitive to oxidative stress. They are at increased risk of 
hemolysis due to the oxidant property of primaquine. Therefore, before initiating primaquine 
therapy, the G6PD status of the patient has to be determined. Passage of dark color urine is an 
indication of hemolysis and the drug has to be stopped if it occurs. Quinine, chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine can also cause hemolysis in G6PD deficient 
patients, but the incidence is less compared to primaquine. 430 
Sold by @itachibot 431
